content.description:
P1 P1. 5.10b, 5 bolts, 10m. Start by a big boulder that is sticking out of the water in early season. Traverse up and left on a crimp/flake with tricky footwork and do a “flexibility test” high-step onto another flake (crux). Finish on easy face to a semi hanging belay. 

P2. 5.12a, 11 bolts, 25m. One of the best 12s at the crag. From P1 belay station step up and right laybacking on the jugs reaching first no hands rest. Do an airy traverse right climbing to the base of first roof. Pull the roof on the crimps (1st crux) to the huge jugs and second no hands rest below another two-step roof. Climb through first step (easy) and pull the second step on the cool wavy sloppers (2nd crux). If you fall look around maybe you missed something;). Climb two slab steps to the chain belay/rap station. 

Descent: 28m rap brings you to the ground.

Note. It is possible to combine P1 and 2 with some rope drag or do the whole climb as one crazy pitch (recommended) with a minimal rope drag, bring 1-2 alpine draws if you plan to do that.

Named in the memory of Andrew Abel. 



Right side of the canyon roughly in front of "Son of a Mitch". In the early season you may want to start from the big boulder that is sticking out of the creek.

Gear: 11-16 draws depending on the link up scenario, 60m rope. Bring 1-2 alpine draws if you are linking pitches.

climbs.name: Always on belay, Nate

content.description:
P1. 5.10b, 5 bolts, 10m. Shared with “Andrew variation”.

P2. 5.9, 4 bolts, 10m. Do one or two reachy moves (crux, 5.9) using high hand holds and walk right up the ledge to a good ledge with chain belay station.

P3. 5.11b, 9 bolts, 20m. Again, one of the best pitches in Little Russia for its grade. Step left, clip the first bolt and climb up to the powerful layback flake. Traverse left clip the bolt from a good two finger sidepull and reach to huge jugs that came out of the climbing gym (crux). Go right onto exposed arête. Climbing and views of the waterfalls get really good here. Pull the arête and get onto a wavy slab with a couple more of tricky moves to the chain belay/rap station. 

Note. It is possible to combine P1 and 2 with some rope drag or do the whole climb as one pitch with a lot of rope drag (not recommended), bring alpine draws if you are into that stuff:)

Descent: 27m rap brings you to the ground.

Named in the memory of Nathaniel Johnson



Right side of the canyon, roughly in front of "Son of a Mitch".

11-16 draws depending on the link up scenario, 60m rope.
Most recent addition to the Little Russia. Climbs named in the memory of our friends whom we lost in the mountains. Steep wall with excellent limestone and varied climbing.
